stream_context.summary: Kaze hosts Sauraen (F3DEX3 microcode author) on a live call to diagnose why the newer F3DEX3 build performs worse in Return to Yoshi’s Island than older microcode/F3DEX2. They A/B test versions, disable lighting, and add new microcode profiling counters (vertex-time/triangle-time, command count, RDP activity) to isolate an unexplained extra ~8–9ms of RSP time. After the call, Kaze returns to level work (a Mario Kart 64 “retro pipe” area) and discusses design details (train race, obstacles), plus a brief personal/business anecdote about ROM-hack repro carts being sold at events.
level: Course 12  Mario Kart retro pipe area
stream_context.significance_reason: Extended live collaboration with Sauraen reveals a major unresolved performance bottleneck in F3DEX3 integration, establishes concrete profiling methods, and surfaces Kaze’s design constraints (no point lights, emulator reliability, keeping Mario movement central).

findings.summary: Sauraen and Kaze confirm RTYI is unusually RDP-efficient compared to Ocarina of Time scenes Sauraen profiled; F3DEX3’s RDP optimizations can shift the bottleneck to the RSP in RTYI because the game already reduced RDP time and improved vertex buffering/other optimizations.

Baseline measurements: in the tested scene, an older F3DEX3 build shows ~21.7ms GFX task time, while the newer F3DEX3 build shows ~27ms in the same area, implying a significant regression or different waiting behavior between versions.

Kaze does not plan to use true point lights in RTYI (emulator compatibility + art direction); lighting for environments is largely vertex color, while actors can use directional lighting, and some ‘point light’ effects are faked via CPU-driven vertex color changes.
RTYI can have up to ~7 directional lights active at once (computed at runtime for environment/scene needs), even though most world geometry is vertex-colored rather than dynamically lit.
Disabling all microcode lighting in F3DEX3 only reduced frame time by ~2ms in the test scene—less than expected—suggesting lighting alone does not explain the full F3DEX3 slowdown.

Sauraen explains a key architectural difference: F3DEX3 transforms vertices to world space then clip space (and transforms/normalizes normals), enabling features like point lighting and octahedral normal encoding; F3DEX2 can be faster for basic directional lighting by transforming light directions into model space per bone, avoiding per-vertex normal transforms/normalization.

To isolate costs, Sauraen creates and sends a modified F3DEX3 microcode that replaces some existing perf counters with two new counters: RSP cycles spent in vertex processing and RSP cycles spent in triangle processing (plus guidance to update the yield-data footer and plotting code).

New profiling reveals vertex processing (~10ms) + triangle processing (~8ms) accounts for ~18ms, but total RSP time remains ~27ms, leaving ~8–9ms unaccounted for in ‘other’ microcode work; this becomes the main mystery to solve.
Command count profiling shows ~8,000 display-list commands in the tested area—consistent with Sauraen’s expectations and likely not the cause of the missing ~8–9ms.

RDP ‘GCLK alive’/RDP activity indicates RTYI’s RDP is working more than half the time (less stalling than OOT, where Sauraen observed closer to ~1/3 active), reinforcing that RTYI’s pipeline is comparatively efficient and thus more sensitive to added RSP overhead.

Sauraen proposes a potential “F3DEX2.5” direction: a hybrid microcode keeping F3DEX3 features/counters but backporting faster F3DEX2-style lighting/vertex processing if the investigation confirms vertex work is the root bottleneck for RTYI’s needs.

Kaze’s design stance for retro pipes: they are references to pre-end-of-N64-era games, but he avoids turning them into entirely different gameplay (e.g., no drivable kart) to keep Mario 64 movement as the core fun.
findings.quote: We want the fun to be for Mario’s movement and not just random things like that.

findings.summary: Course 12 includes a Mario Kart 64 retro pipe concept with a time-limited race (roughly 40–45 seconds), planned start/finish elements, a moving train (possibly with wagons, smoke particles, and knockback), and added obstacles like Calamari Desert-style cactuses.

Kaze recounts seeing N64 repro carts of ROM hacks sold at MAGFest (including a hack he contributed to, The Missing Link) and notes the uncomfortable reality that others can monetize modders’ work via $50 carts and large online stores.

Kaze expresses strong preference to develop for real N64 hardware rather than deal with emulator variability, while also acknowledging speedrunning’s desire for consistent ‘parity’ even if it means standardizing on a flawed emulator.
findings.quote: Ideally, I wouldn’t have to deal with emulators at all. I just want to make my N64 game.

zeina.summary: Zeina appears briefly via a channel subscription during the post-call segment, indicating ongoing support/visibility during dev streams even when not speaking.

findings.summary: Clarifies F3DEX3’s original goals: add new N64 graphics features while reducing RDP time, with the tradeoff of increased RSP time—usually hidden in RDP-bound scenes (e.g., OOT) but exposed in RTYI’s optimized pipeline.

Provides on-stream microcode education: F3DEX3 does per-vertex world-space transforms + normal transforms/normalization; F3DEX2 avoids per-vertex normal transforms for basic directional lighting by transforming lights per bone instead.

Implements and ships a custom profiling build for RTYI that records vertex-cycle and triangle-cycle timing, and instructs Kaze to update yield-data/footer structures and conversion factors (CPU cycles vs RCP cycles ~62).

Concludes there is likely an additional ~8–9ms cost not explained by vertex/triangle processing, not obviously due to command count or excessive overlay swapping, requiring further microcode-level profiling and follow-up sessions.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Ideally, I wouldn’t have to deal with emulators at all. I just want to make my N64 game.
memorable_quotes.context: Sums up his motivation and frustration: targeting real hardware while navigating emulator inconsistencies.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: All graphics are just about faking it, right?
memorable_quotes.context: Said while discussing ‘glow effects’ and lighting tricks—captures the pragmatic art/tech mindset behind RTYI’s visuals.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: We want the fun to be for Mario’s movement and not just random things like that.
memorable_quotes.context: Explaining why the Mario Kart retro pipe won’t become a full kart-driving mode—core gameplay identity first.

key_stories.title: Why F3DEX3 is slower in RTYI than expected
key_stories.summary: Sauraen joins Kaze live to investigate a surprising regression: newer F3DEX3 runs slower in RTYI than older builds/F3DEX2 in the same scene. They iterate through A/B tests, disable lighting, and add new microcode counters to isolate where the time is going.
key_stories.challenge: F3DEX3 was designed to reduce RDP time, but RTYI is already RDP-efficient; the game becomes RSP-bound and shows a large (~27ms) slowdown with new F3DEX3 without a clear single cause.
key_stories.process: They compare old/new microcode timings, test F3DEX2 vs old EX3, temporarily remove all lighting, attempt to remove occlusion-plane work (with some broken rendering during live edits), then implement new counters for vertex and triangle cycle timing and enable command-count sampling.
key_stories.outcome: Vertex (~10ms) + triangle (~8ms) time only explains ~18ms of the ~27ms total, leaving an unexplained ~8–9ms ‘other’ cost. Sauraen plans to think through further profiling approaches and possibly a tailored ‘F3DEX2.5’ hybrid.
key_stories.key_quote: Vertex processing (~10ms) + triangle processing (~8ms) accounts for ~18ms, but total RSP time remains ~27ms.

key_stories.title: Lighting strategy: real-time directional lights + faked point lights
key_stories.summary: In explaining why point lights are off the table, Kaze describes RTYI’s lighting approach: world geometry is mostly vertex-colored, actor lighting uses directional lights, and some local light effects are faked by CPU-updating vertex colors.
key_stories.challenge: Achieve attractive lighting effects on real hardware and across emulators without heavy microcode features like point lights.
key_stories.process: Use vertex-baked colors for environments; compute directional lights at runtime (sometimes multiple at once); fake localized illumination (e.g., firelight) by adjusting colors/directional light behavior near the player.
key_stories.outcome: A cohesive visual style aligned with RTYI’s constraints, but it complicates microcode performance decisions because F3DEX3’s point-light-oriented architecture may not be needed.

key_stories.title: ROM-hack repro carts being sold at conventions
key_stories.summary: Kaze recalls seeing vendors at MAGFest selling N64 repro carts containing ROM hacks, including The Missing Link (which he contributed to). He notes that none of that revenue goes to Nintendo, but it also doesn’t go to the creators—highlighting a grey-market reality around fan projects.
key_stories.challenge: Unwanted third-party monetization of fan-made work, potentially at scale via online stores.
key_stories.process: Observation and discussion: seeing $50 carts at a booth; noting reports of online stores with massive cumulative sales of repro ROM-hack carts.
key_stories.outcome: Acceptance that it ‘comes with the territory,’ but it’s a potentially important documentary/business tension for the RTYI team to navigate.

key_stories.title: A contributor promised animations and never delivered
key_stories.summary: Kaze mentions a long-running issue: someone offered to create needed animations for a planned ‘Bowser magician’ feature, repeatedly promising delivery since 2021 but never following through.
key_stories.challenge: Feature dependency (animations) stalls planned content; managing reliability of volunteer/community commitments.
key_stories.process: Kaze chose not to rely on open ‘call-ups’ after being strung along; he deprioritized the feature until animations are actually available.
key_stories.outcome: A lesson in team management and scope control for community-driven development.
key_stories.key_quote: That’s why you don’t do call-ups.

key_stories.title: Designing the Mario Kart retro pipe without turning it into Mario Kart
key_stories.summary: Kaze iterates on a Course 12 retro pipe inspired by Mario Kart 64’s Calamari Desert, including a start/finish race structure and a moving train. He explicitly rejects adding drivable karts to avoid undermining the core platforming identity.
key_stories.challenge: Make references feel meaningful without becoming a gimmick that replaces Mario 64’s movement-centric gameplay.
key_stories.process: Build a short timed race, add a moving train (with potential knockback and wagons), include authentic set dressing (cactuses, smoke particles), and tune shortcuts (e.g., a tunnel route) so they’re interesting but not trivial.
key_stories.outcome: A clear guiding principle for cameo/reference content that can inform other retro pipes and the documentary’s ‘respectful reinvention’ theme.

open_questions.context: Profiling shows vertex+triangle timing doesn’t account for total RSP task time; command count seems normal and RTYI is RDP-efficient, so the missing time is likely elsewhere in the microcode pipeline.
questions: What specific routines are included in the remaining ~8–9ms (matrix loads, tiny commands, sync/pipe stalls, overlay switching, FIFO interactions, cache effects)?
Did any recent RTYI-side rendering changes increase ‘misc’ display-list traffic (state changes, color/combiner writes, texture changes) in ways not reflected by command count alone?
What additional counters or trace points will Sauraen add next (per-command-type timing, overlay switch counts, DMA/IMEM load time, RDP sync waits)?
Is the regression reproducible across multiple scenes/levels, or only this heavy-vertex test location?
Could the ‘no changes but 25.5ms  27ms’ variance indicate measurement instability, frame limiter interactions, or build mismatches?

open_questions.context: Sauraen floated a microcode tailored for RTYI: F3DEX3 plus backported F3DEX2-style lighting/vertex processing for speed, given RTYI’s limited need for point lights.
questions: What exact F3DEX3 features does RTYI truly need (e.g., cel shading, ambient occlusion, occlusion plane, extended vertex formats)?
What would be the minimum viable hybrid that keeps RTYI’s needed features while restoring EX2-like vertex throughput?
How would maintaining a custom hybrid impact long-term tooling, compatibility, and future contributors?

open_questions.topic: Final adoption path for new GBI / F3DEX3 (and current ‘Mario has no colors’ bug)
open_questions.context: Kaze is mid-transition to the new microcode/GBI; Mario’s colors are broken until RTYI’s lighting calls are updated to match the new command set.
questions: What is the specific GBI change that breaks Mario’s coloration (vertex format, lighting command, material setup)?
Who on the team will handle the ‘trivial’ lighting/GBI fix, and what testing is required on hardware/emulators?
Does the team plan to ship with F3DEX2 first and upgrade later, or block release on F3DEX3 performance parity?

open_questions.topic: RTYI lighting philosophy under emulator constraints
open_questions.context: Kaze avoids true point lights and leans on vertex colors + directional lights (sometimes multiple) and CPU-driven fakes (e.g., fire).
questions: Which emulators are must-pass targets, and what specific lighting features tend to break across them?
How does Kaze implement CPU ‘fake point lights’ (frequency, affected geometry, distance falloff, performance cost)?
Are there visual moments where Kaze wishes he could use point lights, and how does he compensate artistically?

open_questions.topic: Course 12 race design details (train, timer, shortcut tuning)
open_questions.context: Kaze describes a 40–45 second race with a tunnel shortcut and a looping train; he’s deciding how the train affects route choice and fairness.
questions: How will the timer be communicated (HUD, audio cues) and what are the pass/fail conditions?
Will the train be an obstacle, a moving platform, or both (including knockback/launch behavior)?
How will Kaze prevent the tunnel shortcut from invalidating the intended route (train gating, hazards, time loss)?
Will there be multiple intended skill routes for speedrunners vs casual players?

open_questions.topic: Retro pipe ‘reference’ rules across the whole game
open_questions.context: Kaze says each level gets a retro pipe referencing a pre-N64-lifecycle-end game; he rejects ‘random mode shifts’ like full Mario Kart driving.
questions: What are the full list of planned retro pipe references, and why were those titles chosen?
What are the non-negotiable constraints for a retro pipe (length, mechanics, art style, reward structure)?
How do retro pipes serve the larger RTYI theme and pacing—optional secrets, mission gates, or main path?

open_questions.topic: Handling third-party repro cart sales of RTYI and other hacks
open_questions.context: Kaze saw ROM-hack carts being sold at conventions and mentions large online stores monetizing others’ hacks.
questions: Does the RTYI team plan any public stance or policy on repro cart sellers (ignore, discourage, legal requests)?
How does the team weigh ‘exposure’ vs exploitation when others sell the work?
Would the team ever pursue an official physical release (homebrew-friendly) to undercut grey-market sellers, and what legal risks would that create?

open_questions.topic: Volunteer reliability and pipeline dependencies (animations example)
open_questions.context: A promised animation contribution stalled a feature since 2021, shaping Kaze’s view of open call-outs.
questions: What process does Kaze now use to vet contributors and avoid long dependency traps (milestones, small test tasks, contracts)?
Which current RTYI features are still blocked on art/animation/audio deliverables?
How does Kaze balance ‘community involvement’ with the need for predictable shipping timelines?

open_questions.topic: Hardware workflow bottlenecks and tooling choices
open_questions.context: Kaze uses Everdrive X5; Sauraen offers a SummerCart64 and describes rapid USB upload scripts; Kaze also mentions unstable OBS and slow/finicky upload workflows.
questions: What is Kaze’s current build-test loop time on real hardware, and what are the biggest bottlenecks?
Would adopting SummerCart64 or improved scripts materially accelerate iteration, and what stopped that earlier?
How often do hardware-vs-emulator differences force rework, and what’s the team’s testing matrix?

open_questions.topic: Scene complexity: vertex counts and where performance budgets go
open_questions.context: They reference a scene around ~6,600 vertices and discuss how RTYI’s pipeline differs from OOT in vertex/RDP balance.
questions: Which levels/areas are the worst-case vertex/triangle scenes in RTYI, and what visual features cause them?
Does Kaze have formal per-level performance budgets (vertex count, draw calls, particles) and enforcement tools?
What tradeoffs is Kaze willing to make (LOD, occlusion, fog, material simplification) if F3DEX3 can’t be made fast enough?
